I‚Äôve been excited at the start of a year before.¬†2026 is the first time it feels hard-earned.


Not because everything is perfect. Not because things suddenly got easy. But because 2025 was a grind. And it set us up for something real.

Last year asked everything of this team. Hard product calls. Failed bets. Brutal feedback loops. Constant iteration.

And now, coming into 2026, we‚Äôre coming out of the gates with momentum, and you can feel it across the entire team.

We started 2025 as an API-only product for structuring web data and PDFs, working with a handful of early design partners.

We‚Äôre entering 2026 as a real platform that revenue teams rely on ‚Äî connecting messy internal data with the external context they need, letting non-technical users ask questions in minutes that used to take days (or were impossible).

December alone had more growth than the rest of the year combined. That didn‚Äôt feel like luck. It felt like signal.

The path here wasn‚Äôt linear.

We spent the first half of the year betting heavily on web data. 

It got attention, but it didn‚Äôt turn into a durable business. Demand was often one-off. Margins were tough. The people who cared most weren‚Äôt willing to pay what it would take to build it properly.

Mid-year, we made a very uncomfortable, non-consensus decision: stop selling an API and build a frontend where AI agents do the work we used to hand-build for customers, giving non-technical teams the same power we had in Python.

The summer was brutal. 

We put unfinished product in front of real users and let it break ‚Äî sometimes spectacularly. We failed UX tests. We got humbled. And we learned fast.

By the fall, things started to click.

When we tried to serve everyone, we served no one. When we focused on RevOps teams, everything snapped into place.

Sales cycles shortened. Pilots dropped from months to weeks. Messaging became concrete. Expansion paths to being "the AI Data Team" became obvious.

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm so excited about Q1 2026 and the year ahead.

Most importantly, the entire team feels this momentum. The video attached is them, in their own words, on why they believe this year is different.

Nothing meaningful gets built alone. We‚Äôre incredibly grateful to everyone who helped us get here ‚Äî and we‚Äôre just getting started.


P.S. If you‚Äôre on a revenue team and still stitching together answers from scattered data, we built this for you so let's talk.

P.P.S And if you want to be part of a team that earned its momentum the hard way, the video attached is why I‚Äôm betting on 2026.

Every holiday season for the past 5 years, my family has kept a simple tradition. It's changed how I look at each new year.

We do "words of the year." Around New Year‚Äôs dinner, everyone shares:
1. the word they chose last year
2. how honestly they lived up to it
3. and the word they‚Äôre choosing for the year ahead

Last year, my word was Priorities ‚Äî and its less-talked-about twin: Sacrifice

And to be clear, it worked.

It was a big year. A successful one. Professionally and personally, a lot moved forward.

I heavily prioritized work. The back half of the year was strong. We grew the team, built a ton of product, fixed real issues in enterprise onboarding, and honestly‚Ä¶ it felt like the year we became real. 2025 set us up well for 2026.

But here‚Äôs the reflection I shared with my family:

When you prioritize hard, you also sacrifice ‚Äî often in quieter ways you don‚Äôt notice until later.

For me, that sacrifice showed up as mess.

Not metaphorically. My life kinda became an actual, tangible mess.

- My apartment still wasn‚Äôt fully moved in halfway through my lease.
- My bedroom didn‚Äôt even have furniture for the first 3‚Äì4 months.
- My phone had 1,000+ unread texts.
- My inbox was a constant low-grade source of stress.
- My health took a real hit.
- My desk became a void for items of all sorts to disappear.
- My to-do lists were scrawled across a variety of half-used notebooks.

The ironic part?

I spend my days building tools to structure messy data ‚Äî while my own life became increasingly unstructured.

Productive chaos, sure.
But still chaos.

So my word for this year is Clean.

Not extreme. Not obsessive. Just‚Ä¶ intentional.

- Clean body: eating better, moving more, feeling healthier.
- Clean space: unpacked apartment, clear desk, fewer piles.
- Clean digital life: inboxes, texts, to-dos that don‚Äôt quietly drain mental energy.
- Clean relationships: fewer habits, commitments, and dynamics that don‚Äôt add real value.

I want ‚Äúclean‚Äù to mean starting the day without mental or physical clutter ‚Äî no background noise about where things are or what I forgot ‚Äî so I can focus on high-leverage things that actually matter.

And importantly, I‚Äôm not trying to optimize this to death.

No perfect systems. No detoxes. No hustle cosplay.

Just what feels good, sustainable, and within reach.

Part of why this tradition works is accountability ‚Äî saying it out loud, letting the people around you who matter remember it with you.

So here it is, publicly:
Last year was Priorities.
This year is Clean.


P.S. If you had to pick one word for this year, what would it be? And how can we keep each other accountable for it?

To all my connections out there who want an AI tool that is incredibly powerful at finding data, organizing unstructured data, and helping with analysis (among many things), I have a recommendation for you - Structify! 

Funny enough, I wasn't actually looking for this product but had the fortune to see a post about it right here on Linkedin that a friend, Hovhannes M., had shared. Though we know one another from our Harvard-Yale days, I didn't know Hovhannes was also working in the data science sphere. This product was also a pleasant surprise to discover since at that time I was working on some interesting data structure and analysis problems, but not sure where to go next. 

As most of you probably know, I am a data scientist by trade, but also have been promoting my new novel, "In the Shadow of Mount Khustup". While doing book promotion (which mostly has happened using social media and in person book talks), I always felt that craving to make my decisions informed by data. This includes things like finding the right people to partner with, organizations which would be supportive, grants and opportunities related to writing etc. I also had some metrics from my own sources on Instagram, Amazon KDP, and of course my favorite Linkedin üôÇ . Where Structify came in was being that tool through which I could use to not only search the web to find information I need, but also upload my own data to and have its AI help me analyze all of these different sources of data. 

Truthfully, this was the product that I wish had existed YEARS ago when some of my roles required me to parse through hundreds of datasets on the internet and work with both unstructured and structured data that I already had. I also discovered it was very helpful for me to get a second opinion about what my data showed or had the potential to show.

I have been using it for about a month so far and really enjoy the experience. Though I don't have a massive database yet or tons of different files, it is something I honestly recommend for mid-size and large firms that want to scale up and make sense of their data which might otherwise just be sitting idly in some kind of database.

If you work in a company where you face the same problems I had or the ones I mentioned above, I recommend you give Structify a shot! For those of you wondering, I also compared it to ChatGPT and Gemini, and it knocks them out of the water in my opinion üî•

For those who are curious what it actually looks like, I have a screenshot attached of one of the project workflows which Structify created based on my prompt, and the outcome was very impressive. If you are interested, I suggest you sign up and to try it yourself!

#structify #AI #usefultools #data #structureddata #unstructureddata

Just had an EOY budget reality check: we found $2k/mo of spend we didn‚Äôt know we had.


Not because we weren‚Äôt paying attention ‚Äî but because visibility is hard when answers are buried across a ton of sources.

We were wrapping up budgets before the holidays and someone asked a simple question in Slack:

‚ÄúCan you pull in our AWS spending information?‚Äù

@Structify responded in-thread with this graph.

That‚Äôs when we saw it: AWS SageMaker running. No one actively using it. ~$1,200/month.

Thankfully it was credits, not cash ‚Äî but still. We stopped it immediately.

Honestly? I don‚Äôt think we would‚Äôve caught this otherwise.

This is what‚Äôs changed for us since shipping our Slack bot:
- We‚Äôre not guessing about spend anymore
- We‚Äôre not waiting for finance reviews or dashboards
- We‚Äôre making real budget decisions in seconds, where we already work

We‚Äôre a team of <10 people. We don‚Äôt have a finance or analytics department. But now we can see ‚Äî clearly ‚Äî what‚Äôs running, what‚Äôs costing us money, and what needs to be shut off.

Honestly, founders should be able to know every meaningful detail about their business in seconds. Not at the end of the quarter. Not during board prep. Not after money‚Äôs gone.

But the reality is it's hard to keep a pulse on things.

This discovery also pushed us to ship something new: We now have ongoing spend monitoring dashboards that:
1. Track infra + tool spend
2. Detect spikes
3. Push alerts directly into Slack

The goal is simple: stay lean, stay aware, and never be surprised by your own business.

Visibility beats vibes ‚Äî especially when budgets are tight.

This week, I lost an argument with our own data.
And it happened in Slack.


I was debating which outbound strategies to prioritize for Q1 with the team. 

Lots of smart opinions, but lots of ‚ÄúI think‚Äùs (tbh especially from me).

Then Hovik typed a question to @Structify: 
"What outbound channels are working and what's not?"

Less than a minute later, the answer showed up in-thread ‚Äî backed by our actual data.

I was wrong. And honestly? It ruled.

We just shipped "Structi" Slackbot where you can ask questions of your data ‚Äî internal or external ‚Äî and get answers directly in Slack threads.

Since shipping it, we‚Äôve never used our own product more.

We‚Äôre a team of <10 people, and this week alone we‚Äôve asked hundreds of questions we simply wouldn‚Äôt have asked before:

- Revenue and GTM performance
- Outbound comparisons month-over-month
- Product usage and power users
- Pipeline stalls and slow deals
- Random office questions we used to answer with vibes

Before this, the options were:

A) ‚ÄúDirectionally correct‚Äù guesses
B) Clicking through 5 different tools
C) Writing pipelines we didn‚Äôt have time to write
D) Or most common‚Ä¶ just not answering the question at all

Now we‚Äôre being pinpoint accurate ‚Äî without an analytics team.

Slack is where we live, so that‚Äôs where we put the product. Reducing friction matters more than almost anything else.

The most interesting part has been dogfooding it this hard. Using it constantly forces us to sweat the small stuff. Centering graphs. Axis alignment. Labels that actually make sense in context.

All the tiny nits that make the difference between ‚Äúcool demo‚Äù and ‚Äúaddictive product.‚Äù

(Yes ‚Äî an actual customer told us it‚Äôs addictive. When you get one answer, it sparks five more questions. Pandora‚Äôs box, but in a good way.)

When your team can ask real questions and get real answers instantly, decision-making changes fast.


Sharing a short walkthrough video below!


P.S. Would love feedback ‚Äî and curious what questions you‚Äôd ask your data if it lived in Slack.

If you ask the team what their fav Structify tradition is, they‚Äôll all say the same thing...


Tuesday team lunch!

We do it every week. 

We all step out of the office to try one of the many amazing Williamsburg restaurants near us.

And it's never canceled ‚Äî no matter how intense the day is.

We‚Äôre about 10 people today and planning to double next year, and this one hour is already central to our culture.

Not because it‚Äôs fancy.
Not because it‚Äôs clever.
But because it‚Äôs protected.

Founders obsess over ‚Äúculture.‚Äù Honestly, it‚Äôs simpler than we make it.

Everyone overcomplicates culture with decks, values docs, and offsites.

But culture usually comes down to what you repeat ‚Äî and what you refuse to cancel.

Tuesday lunch forces us out of the office.

It forces us to sit down and talk about whatever.

It lets us get to know exceptional teammates as people, not just coworkers.

The rules are simple:
1. No work talk.
2. Random seating chart.
3. Alternate who picks the location.
4. No phones. (First person to check theirs has to pay with their Ramp card and submits the reimbursement.)

And yes ‚Äî we love trying new places from Pierozek to K'Far to MaLa Project.

What that builds shows up later.

It shows up during all-nighters turning around pilots.
It shows up when things break and pressure is high.
It shows up in how easily we communicate, how quickly we laugh, and how much we trust each other when it counts.

That‚Äôs culture. It's not mysterious.

It‚Äôs the small things you do on purpose ‚Äî and keep doing, especially when it would be easier not to.

Traditions are how culture scales.


P.S. Apparently Pierozek is the current top-ranking spot.

It's beginning to look a lot like "Ship-mas!"


December in startups is the most wonderful time of year, and at Structify, we've coined it as "Ship-mas."

While most companies start winding down, calendars get lighter, and decisions get pushed to ‚Äúnext year‚Äù ‚Äî we do the opposite.

We lock in. And ship product.

It‚Äôs one of my favorite times of the year because it‚Äôs when real product progress happens. Fewer distractions. Longer focus blocks. A team that‚Äôs aligned and shipping for the long term, not the quarter.

Last December, we did a massive one-week sprint that fundamentally changed our product:

We enabled customers to point us at a website, automatically pull PDFs, structure them, and turn them into something usable for analysis.

It was intense, scrappy, and a huge unlock for how people actually work with messy real-world data. And it culminated in a live demo with the entire team shipping right till the deadline.

This year feels even more special.

Our team is more than double the size, and we‚Äôve spent December heads-down building things that change how our customers interact with data every day:
‚Ä¢ A Slackbot that lets you build analytics, create datasets, and get answers directly where work already happens (this one has changed my day-to-day the most, as I'm a massive power user)
‚Ä¢ A business wiki that automatically organizes every data source across an org into a single map ‚Äî capturing meaning, metadata, and how concepts relate to each other
‚Ä¢ A full product redesign that‚Äôs simpler, cleaner, and more distinctive (less really is more)
‚Ä¢ The ability to turn recurring chat sessions into refreshed dashboards you can rely on over time

It‚Äôs been long days, a lot of shared dinners, and more than a few ‚Äúokay let‚Äôs ship one more thing before the demo‚Äù moments ‚Äî but seeing all of this come together has been incredibly rewarding.

I feel a ton of pride in this team. And a lot of joy in this season.

December is when we quietly build the things that set the tone for the year ahead.

Excited to roll these out and carry this momentum straight into 2026.

resharedPost.text:
Everyone's waiting for the model that finally makes agents work. It came out a year ago.

There's a consensus forming in tech that agents "aren't ready yet." Wait for better reasoning. Wait for the next breakthrough.

We've been shipping agent systems at Structify for months. They explore databases, write code, fix their own mistakes, and produce outputs customers rely on daily. The models aren't the bottleneck. The infrastructure is.
The same LLM that hallucinates wildly in a naive implementation becomes remarkably reliable when you give it the right constraints. Sandboxed execution where a hallucinated rm -rf can't destroy anything. Typed tool interfaces where the agent either produces valid actions or gets actionable errors. Structured state instead of raw chat history that grows until the agent loses the plot.
Here's the insight that changed how we build: nondeterminism compounds. The longer you let an agent spin without external feedback, the more variance accumulates. It's why Claude Code uses Opus for planning and lets smaller models execute each step. The hierarchy introduces checkpoints. Determinism returns at the boundaries.

The other half is letting agents fail gracefully. When you demand perfect success, the agent does whatever it takes to please you‚Äîeven when the task is impossible. This is why LLMs wrap everything in try/except when they generate code. They're optimizing for "didn't crash" rather than "actually worked."
Our agents can say "I don't know." They can surface errors and ask for clarification. They operate in loops where failures feed back into context so the agent can iterate. A frustrating crash becomes a self-correcting cycle.
The gap between demo and production isn't intelligence. It's guardrails, recovery loops, and state management. Build those right and today's models are already good enough.

The breakthrough already satisfies. Cage it.

I didn‚Äôt expect a NYC restaurant to change how I think about building an AI startup. But it did.


This Saturday, my college friend ‚Äî and now part of the Structi-fam ‚Äî Hovik took me to 63 Clinton to celebrate 7+ years of friendship. 

It wasn‚Äôt meant to be a ‚Äúbusiness lesson" or lead to a LinkedIn post. Just two friends catching up and reflecting on the winding path that made us friends in the first place.

But the night did genuinely end up reshaping how I think about hospitality in startups.

From the moment we walked in, the service felt different.

Everyone introduced themselves and shook our hands ‚Äî warm, genuine, effortless. The sommelier, Bobby, didn‚Äôt just pour wine. He told stories about the winemakers he‚Äôs met, why he loves them, what makes each bottle special. His passion made the experience feel personal.

And the food‚Ä¶ The soft scrambled eggs were unreal. The tiramisu was the best I‚Äôve ever had. Yet somehow, the hospitality stood out even more.

So at the end, we asked co-owner Raymond Trinh how they do it.

His answer was simple, but it stuck with me.

1. An exceptional, small team ‚Äî just 11 people. Each person wears many hats. Everyone buys into the mission. It felt exactly like a startup.
2. An obsession with genuine connection. Not reactive service ‚Äî proactive warmth. The feeling of: you belong here and we want to do right by you.

That‚Äôs what makes a restaurant unforgettable. 

And then, the parallel hit us: it‚Äôs what makes startups unforgettable too.

In both restaurants and AI startups, ‚Äúproduct‚Äù only gets you so far.

There are plenty of places with great food. Plenty of startups with great tech.

But the true differentiator is the experience ‚Äî the hospitality, the culture, the humanity behind the product. People remember how you make them feel.

So we decided ‚ÄúMichelin-star hospitality‚Äù will be part of our DNA.

Not just when a bug happens. Not just when something‚Äôs broken.

But from the first interaction ‚Äî through onboarding, support, and every moment in between.

Bugs are inevitable in software (just like the occasional undercooked steak in a kitchen). What matters is the foundation of trust, warmth, and care that surrounds those moments.

A simple dinner between two friends became one of the clearest reminders of what actually sets companies apart.

And I left 63 Clinton not just full ‚Äî but inspired, grateful, and convinced that hospitality is one of the most underrated superpowers a startup can have.


P.S. It got a 10.0 rating on my Beli :) Thank you Hovik!!

Our strongest team ritual¬†started with a single, mind-blowing bite of togarashi smoked salmon.


Every team has a moment when ‚Äúculture‚Äù goes from something abstract‚Ä¶ to something you can actually taste.

For us, it's¬†Fish Friday.

Back when we were just three people, our CTO, Alex Goldstein ‚Äî resident foodie and relentless Beli user ‚Äî walked into the office holding a bag of smoked salmon from Acme Smoked Fish Corp that a friend had been urging him to try.

I took one bite.

And I swear: best bite of fish I‚Äôve ever had in my life.

It's so rare that I take a single bite and know something is the best of a category, but this was it.

So Alex and I made an on-the-spot decision:
Every Friday, we stop what we‚Äôre doing, grab a table, and share bagels and lox together.

Sometimes it‚Äôs jalape√±o‚Äìtequila salmon (my personal favorite).
Sometimes blueberry dill (surprisingly good).

But the ritual is always the same: sit down, breathe out, and talk about the week.
(Even from JFK Terminal 8 before our team offsite)

And every single Friday, we have this moment where someone says:
‚ÄúWait‚Ä¶ that happened this week?!?‚Äù

Because startup time is elastic, and these little pauses remind us how much we actually move.

Over time, Fish Friday became one of our strongest cultural anchors.

Alex G and I insisted on keeping it alive, and now newer teammates like Nico carry the torch. Even Hovik ‚Äî who doesn‚Äôt even like smoked salmon (objectively a bad take, please flame him for it) ‚Äî shows up and gets into it.

But here‚Äôs the real lesson:
Culture scales when the rituals do.

Not the offsites, not the slogans ‚Äî the tiny, consistent traditions that make the work week feel like something you‚Äôre building together.

Fish Friday started as an accident.

Now it‚Äôs a tradition I want us to keep as we grow ‚Äî a reminder that small things, repeated often, compound into something meaningful.

Yesterday, I stumbled into Prudential HQ, entirely on fumes, supposed to present to a room full of execs and tech leaders.


What they¬†didn‚Äôt¬†know: I had just pulled an all-nighter.

We were onboarding a new customer with some very ‚Äúfun‚Äù data configurations, which meant tweaking parts of our product in real time.

By the time I finally hit save on everything, it was basically morning‚Ä¶ and I still had¬†no deck.

So I built the presentation a few hours before walking on stage.

On the trek to Newark, I felt like absolute garbage ‚Äî the kind of exhausted where you‚Äôre questioning every life choice. I threw on some funk jazz just to keep my spirits above sea level.

But if I‚Äôm going to do something, I commit. So when I stepped on stage, I brought every ounce of energy I had left.

And something wild happened...

People looked up from their phones.

They nodded (voraciously). They leaned in. Even when I slipped up once or twice, they stayed with me.

Afterward, my table was packed with people wanting to talk ‚Äî all resonating with what I presented: the inevitable¬†‚Äúdata swamp.‚Äù

    The reality inside most enterprises isn‚Äôt a pristine data lake or warehouse.
    It‚Äôs a swamp ‚Äî disconnected, messy, impossible to fully drain.
    You don't need the lake/warehouse (it's an unachievable ideal).
    You need a way to make the swamp¬†usable.

One person said, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs exactly how it feels to use our data.‚Äù
Another: ‚ÄúGreat energy.‚Äù

Founder's reality is never as polished as it looks from the outside.

Some days it‚Äôs fire drills ‚Üí no sleep ‚Üí long commutes ‚Üí onstage with a half-built deck.

But when you show up with authenticity and a different energy, people feel it.

P.S. Huge shoutout to¬†Justin Murray and Alberto Gutierrez¬†for putting together such a great expo. Grateful I got to be part of it ‚Äî even on zero sleep.

resharedPost.text:
The Hidden Tax Bleeding American Enterprise

Every company pays a tax no one talks about. It doesn't show up on a balance sheet. It shows up as decisions made on bad data, and nobody knows until it's too late.

Palantir built a $50 billion company trying to fix this. They call it the Operational Ontology. Map your data to real-world objects. It works. But they have to deploy armies to maintain it.

For the rest of us, the dream collapses into Confluence pages nobody reads.

We onboarded a client who had tried building this in house. Six months of work. Hundreds of wiki pages. Then they acquired a competitor. Different CRM, different warehouse, different naming conventions. Their "customer" included trial accounts. The parent company's didn't. Revenue in Salesforce on one side, Netsuite on the other.

Why does this keep happening?

Because we're chasing Plato's dream. Perfect Forms. The ideal Customer. The ideal Churn. Discover the true definition, write it down, enforce it.

But meaning isn't sitting somewhere waiting to be discovered. Meaning is use. "Customer" means something different to sales than to finance than to support. Not because someone is wrong. Because they're doing different jobs. The meaning lives in the queries people run, the filters they apply, the logic they write.

This is a new feature we're building at Structify. Instead of forcing people to memorize the official definition, we use LLMs to watch how concepts are actually used across the org, and reuse them in an observable manner. In queries, dashboards, conversations. Instead of six weeks defining something, six minutes seeing how it's already being used.

More soon.

I‚Äôm calling BS on SF 9.9.6. culture. If you gotta announce it, you‚Äôre doing something wrong.


I was in San Francisco last week, and so many people I met seemed suddenly obsessed with this idea of ‚Äú9.9.6.‚Äù

Working from 9am to 9pm, six days a week. People literally put it on a billboard in Jackson Square so everyone knows they‚Äôre ‚Äúserious.‚Äù

But let‚Äôs be real: this isn‚Äôt a cultural breakthrough, but a rebrand of something New York has been doing forever.

Anyone who‚Äôs lived or worked in NYC ‚Äî in finance, theater, fashion, media, agencies, tech ‚Äî knows there‚Äôs nothing novel about long hours. 

People push, stretch, produce, rehearse, ship, deliver. No slogans. No self-congratulation. No ‚Äú9.9.6‚Äù identity.

It‚Äôs not just the job. It‚Äôs the norm. And often, it‚Äôs more than 9.9.6.

Our team already works at that pace ‚Äî and we don‚Äôt talk about it because it‚Äôs natural. 

It's not forced, not performative, and not some new operating model we need to market. 

When you genuinely care about what you‚Äôre building, the hours stop feeling like ‚Äúhours.‚Äù 

Leaning into the work comes easy. Especially when it‚Äôs cold outside

We don‚Äôt glorify it, but we don‚Äôt shy away from it either. Honestly, it‚Äôs just how momentum feels.

So when I see SF treating 9.9.6 like it‚Äôs a revolutionary mindset, I can‚Äôt help but laugh a little. 

Hard work isn‚Äôt a trend. It isn‚Äôt a billboard campaign. And it definitely isn‚Äôt something you ‚Äúadopt‚Äù for clout.

If you‚Äôre truly building, you don‚Äôt have to announce your intensity.

You just live it. Everyday.

Did your rep just cold email someone who came to your happy hour last week?


We opened last week‚Äôs newsletter with this, and it drove a 42% open rate & doubled our click-thru.

I was excited to see how it resonated with so many users, but not at all surprised.

Because almost every GTM team has lived through this exact moment:

"Jake Johnson from Acme Corp‚Äù shows up as...

- Jake.johnson@acme.com¬†in HubSpot
- j.johnson@gmail.com¬†in your happy hour RSVP
- Jake J. on LinkedIn Sales Nav
- jjohnson@acme.com¬†in your product database

4 ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù people... and 0 way of checking this at scale for a fast-moving growth team.

Last Monday,¬†Kelly Li¬†dropped a meme on this exact situation in our¬†#gtm¬†channel. 

By Thursday night, Alex Goldstein had a PR in. 

Not a patch, but a fix for the¬†root cause.

And that fix became something bigger...

Structify now recognizes when different records all refer to the same person, company, or entity ‚Äî even when the data doesn‚Äôt match perfectly.

Unlike traditional ‚Äúfuzzy matching,‚Äù which just hunts for similar text, Structify understands context and uses dozens of signals¬†to make accurate, intelligent connections across your disparate GTM stack.

For a growth team, this means:

1) Complete visibility over every touchpoint even when they use different emails. From 1st LinkedIn message ‚Üí in-person event ‚Üí demo ‚Üí conversion.

2) No more ‚Äúnew lead‚Äù emails to existing customers or duplicate outreach from different team members.

3) Finally see which campaigns actually drive conversion when you can connect all the metrics across all GTM tools.

That 42% engagement told me 1 thing clear.

Teams are¬†hungry¬†for cleaner, connected, reliable GTM data.

Smart Matching is a big step toward making that the norm.

I‚Äôve stopped doing polished, pre-recorded, ‚Äúnothing-can-go-wrong‚Äù demos. Live demos ONLY.


Being a founder of an AI startup is a game of trust, and honestly, vulnerability.

Life‚Äôs too short to not be upfront with folks.

Customers can feel when you‚Äôre being genuine. A live demo forces you to show the product as it actually is ‚Äî strengths, quirks, rough edges and all. 

And in a world where everyone is fighting for trust (especially after the MIT study that 95% of AI POCs fail), showing up authentically matters more than ever.

Because there‚Äôs still just a ton of vaporware out there.

Everyone has seen the flashy videos & perfect screenshots, but so many of these products still break the moment you try a real use case.

We build AI-driven analytics designed to make getting answers to data questions actually easier ‚Äî not just in a demo environment, but in a customer‚Äôs real workflow.

So when I meet with someone, I start by asking questions. I listen. I pay attention to their real scenario‚Ä¶ 

And then I spin up a live demo for that exact use case. No scripted paths. No preloaded datasets. Real stuff on the fly.

And sure ‚Äî I‚Äôll be honest: something almost always goes wrong. 

That‚Äôs okay. 

We‚Äôre a startup. No one expects perfection. What people do expect is honesty. 

If a feature is new, I say it. If something glitches, I acknowledge it (make the ticket right then and there in front of the potential customer) and keep going.

Because trust doesn‚Äôt start after the contract is signed ‚Äî it starts in that very first conversation.

And in my experience? A founder demo-ing a product that breaks live builds trust faster than anything else.

Because they know the next time I talk to them, I‚Äôm going to open with: ‚ÄúWe fixed that and here‚Äôs what‚Äôs new.‚Äù

I turned 26 this past weekend, and I felt something I‚Äôve never fully understood before.


On Saturday, I spent my birthday doing a big, chaotic, bottomless brunch with some of my favorite people (plug for De Mole Williamsburg, the best spot). 

At one point I looked around the table‚Äîpeople from different chapters of my life all crammed together‚Äîand I finally had the words to describe the feeling I had...

‚ÄúCompounded Gratitude."

When I was in high school, our principal Dr. O‚ÄôReilly preached ‚Äúgratitude‚Äù like it was a daily vitamin. I didn‚Äôt get it. It felt abstract.

But now? I‚Äôve seen enough of the arc to realize nothing about life is self-made.

Not my work, not my education, not my mindset, not my value, nothing. 

It‚Äôs all an accumulation: people, moments, late-night conversations, support that shows up in tiny ways.

Especially as a founder.

People talk about the journey being isolating, and sometimes it is. But for me, the hard moments aren‚Äôt fixed by solitude‚Äîthey‚Äôre fixed by hopping on a train to see a friend, grabbing dinner after a brutal sprint, or texting someone who‚Äôll show up without asking for context.

That‚Äôs my version of a car breaking down on the side of the road: me breaking down. And knowing I can call people who will pick me up every single time.

That kind of support builds on itself. It compounds.

And if you‚Äôre paying attention, so does the gratitude. 

And that was what Dr. O‚ÄôReilly was talking about. I finally get it.

Today, I‚Äôm grateful for:
‚Äì friends who drop everything for a quick dinner
‚Äì a family I‚Äôll never stop being lucky to have
‚Äì long conversations over food
‚Äì my heated blanket after a long day
‚Äì and a life that‚Äôs stitched together by people who made it possible, often without ever realizing it

26 feels good.

Not because of what I‚Äôve achieved, but because of who‚Äôs been in the bus with me the whole time.

Thank you to everyone who stayed by my side from my inaugural birthday to the most recent and to all the ones left to come.

I analyzed every Nobel Prize winner since 1901. The most successful countries aren't just producing geniuses - they're also importing them.

Since 1990, nearly half of American Nobel laureates were born somewhere else.
The pattern is always the same:

- Born in developing country
- Educated in Europe
- Hired by American university
- Wins Nobel "for America"

But that's not even the wildest part.

Discovery #1: We Already Know 2054's Winners

The average Nobel laureate wins at age 60 for work done at 30.

That means 2054's winners already published their breakthroughs. Today.

The committee's just waiting for "historical validation."

Discovery #2: Small Countries Dominate (Per Capita)

- Switzerland: 1 Nobel per 58,000 citizens
- USA: 1 per 870,000
- India: 1 per 4.7 million

It's not population. It's funding density.

Discovery #3: No Pattern Within Fields

Analyzed subcategories across every discipline. Expected to find trends.
Found chaos.

Physics jumps from quantum to cosmology to condensed matter randomly. Chemistry swings wildly between subfields.

The only predictable thing? Geography and age.

The youngest winner ever was 17 (Malala).

The oldest was 90 (Hurwicz).

Most fall right at 60, collecting lifetime achievement awards for work that changed the world three decades ago.

I flew to Phoenix for exactly 24 hours on 2 hours of sleep to attend a conference in an industry I knew nothing about. It completely changed my perspective on AI in legacy industries.

I'm standing in the Phoenix Convention Center at 7 AM, running on conference coffee and pure adrenaline. Gabe (our Chief of Staff) and I are easily the youngest people in the room.

Which meant there was a lot we could learn from talking with literally anyone there.

I walk up to a group discussing grid reliability. They stop talking.

"Hi, we build AI tools. We know nothing about power. Can you teach us?"

Silence.

Then one guy laughs. "At least you're honest. Sit down."

For the next while, he draws diagrams on napkins. Generation -> Transmission -> Distribution. They are laser-focused on any risk that could impact any of those areas.

They drove home an appreciation for reliability and affordability. Just think: a 5-minute blackout affecting 10,000 people equals 833 person-hours of impact. And how much did those people pay to know that they could keep the lights on?

I learned about how many have their own pLTE, a private cellular network. 

"If AT&T fails during a hurricane, we still need comms to restore power," one exec told me.

Another executive pulls me aside between sessions:

"You know what keeps me up? We have smart meters generating terabytes of data. Can AI predict transformer events and anomalies?"

That question changed everything.

These weren't technology-resistant dinosaurs. They were engineers drowning in complexity, looking for solutions--for innovation.

By hour 20, Gabe and I are exhausted but wired. We've filled our notebooks. Had dozens of conversations. Our entire view of the landscape has shifted.

On the way to the airport, we stop at JT's Wings - this complete dive bar our Phoenix client recommended. Best wings I've ever had. We're eating standing up, about to miss our flight, mapping out new strategies on napkins covered in wing sauce.

Red-eye back. No sleep. Straight to the office.

We learned something that no other AI founder has. 

All because we were willing to be the dumbest people in a room for 24 hours.

We pulled data from New York, Paris, and Milan Fashion Weeks. Here‚Äôs what the numbers reveal about the industry‚Äôs future.

What we found revealed a massive business opportunity hiding in plain sight.

We started by looking at ownership structures. 

Paris and Milan looked exactly how you'd expect: Legacy brands like LVMH and Kering control everything. They‚Äôre closed ecosystems that've been running the same way for decades.

Then we looked at New York.

87% of shows came from independently-owned brands. No conglomerate backing. No billionaire parent companies. Just founders building their own houses in real-time.

We almost didn't believe it at first, so we cross-referenced with brand age data.

American brands weren't just independent. They were young, with most founded in the last 10 years. While Paris showcased houses with century-long legacies, New York's runways were filled with brands that barely existed five years ago.

That's when we realized: this isn't just a different market. 

It's a business opportunity.

How? Because young, independent U.S. brands need everything. From manufacturing partners to supply chain relationships to investors. In Paris and Milan? Those partnerships are already locked up. 

Most B2B companies are chasing European heritage houses, but they're missing hundreds of independent U.S. brands that will define the next decade.

Smart operators are already hopping on the U.S. fashion opportunity:

- Manufacturing partners locking in favorable long-term deals
- Tech companies building for independent fashion operations
- Investors writing smaller checks to more founders
- Service providers positioning as "the indie fashion partner"

The window is now. The founders showing at NYFW this year will have scaled, raised capital, or been acquired in two years. The partnerships you build now compound as they grow.

How‚Äôd we find this out?

We used Structify to collect and structure data from fashion week schedules, brand databases, and press releases across hundreds of brands. Weeks of research in hours.

No matter the industry, if you're sitting on market data that could reveal your next business opportunity, check out the link in comments below. Let‚Äôs chat.

You wouldn‚Äôt know it but there‚Äôs a fire in this room that is minutes away from destroying everything we built. 

This photo was taken at 9 AM on launch day. Two hours until we show the world Structify - our "vibe data engineering" platform that enables anyone to build data automations with no code.

What you can't see: We'd been up all night fixing disasters.

2 AM: The "final" launch video arrives. I thought we had things sorted and then...

2:30 AM: Alex Goldstein discovers a bug that breaks everything. We have to wake up Alex Reichenbach from actual sleep to help fix it.

3 AM: I'm pacing past our task board. Hundreds of sticky notes from three weeks of work falling off the wall. All of it worthless if we can't fix these issues.

4 AM: Bug finally fixed. Everything held together nicely.

I hadn't been home since Sunday. Same hoodie on since my flight back from a conference earlier that week. Suitcase under my desk. My apartment still in boxes from moving a month ago. 

Admittedly, I stooped to actually buying a toothbrush from CVS earlier that week because I'd been living in the office.

By the time this photo was taken, we were running on pure adrenaline. You can probably see computers everywhere, maybe some tired faces if you look close enough.

What you can't see is the panic from six hours earlier when everything was broken.

11 AM: We launch anyway.

48 hours later: One million views. Hundreds of signups. Twitter exploding.

Every successful launch you've seen looked exactly like this room six hours before.

Broken code. Exhausted team. Everything on fire.

The only difference? They launched anyway.

Most engineers don't know it yet, but these two guys in Brooklyn just made their $200K salaries unnecessary.

Last month, I was sponsoring one of Andrew Yeung's dinners in Manhattan. Just finished my pitch about Dealroom Media when this young guy taps my shoulder as I'm heading out.

"We should talk."

I turn around. He looked maybe 22.

"What are you building?"

"We're enabling anybody to have a $500k/year data team in their pocket." I almost laughed. Then he opened his laptop. 

Alex Reichenbach (CEO of Structify) showed me something that made my jaw drop. Every company drowning in unstructured data needs a $500K/year data engineering team. Most can't afford it. So their data sits there, useless.

His solution: AI that lets anyone build data pipelines with prompts. Like Lovable, but for data engineering. 

"Holy sh*t, this is going to be massive."

Every week, Alex and Ronak Gandhi (co-founder) would send me updates. User growth. Enterprise deals are in the pipeline. The type of traction that makes VCs salivate.

Then last Thursday, he texts me at 7 AM: "We're launching today. Want to swing by the office to help with our launch post?

I cancelled my morning meetings and grabbed an Uber.

9 AM. I walk into their office. The entire team hasn't slept.

Ronak is running on a 30-minute power nap. They've been debugging since 4 AM. Energy, as if they'd mainlined pure caffeine.

Then, 15 minutes before launch, a critical bug threatens to destroy everything. Months of prep, $4.1M raised, and now the whole thing might have to be delayed.

I'm watching Ronak and their CTO frantically rewriting code while the countdown timer on the wall keeps ticking. Nobody's talking. Just keyboards clicking and that timer getting louder in everyone's head.

Three minutes left. Ronak hits enter. "Fixed."

Launch goes live.

Within hours: 1 million views. Hundreds of signups. Their Slack is going insane with customer messages.

But here's what stuck with me:

Most founders I meet play startup theater. Talk about "grinding." Leave at 5 PM.

These guys? Their Slack status is permanently green. 2 AM, 6 AM, doesn't matter. Someone's always shipping code.

And they're attacking it like their lives depend on it.

That combination? Unstoppable.

Structify will be worth $1B in 5 years. Mark my words.

We just turned 6 months of data work into 6 minutes. 

Yesterday, we launched Structify Flows.

It's the first platform where you literally just type what you want, like you're complaining at 1am:

"Why are these numbers off?"
"Flag unexpected trends in Q3"
"Make this spreadsheet stop yelling at me"

And it just... does it.

No SQL. No Python. No begging your data team to "get to it next sprint."

Thank you to everyone who believed in the vision, signed up early, and celebrated with us last week. Seeing your faces light up when we demoed "vibe data engineering" reminded me why we built this.

To the 200+ companies already using Structify and everyone commenting "DATA" for early access: you're not just users, you're co-builders of the future of data automation.

Here's to turning messy data into competitive advantage, together üöÄ

We raised $4.1M for this moment: introducing Structify Flows. It's the first ‚Äúvibe data engineering‚Äù platform that lets you do enterprise-grade data work in minutes:

Most companies are drowning in their own data. Scattered systems, messy tables, dusty PDFs, insights trapped in places no human has time to process.

Your data team spends 80% of their time on copy-pasting instead of the high-leverage tasks that move the needle.

The backlog that used to take a 10-person data team 3 months now takes 3 minutes at 1/10th the cost.

Here's what makes Structify different:

1. Vibe data engineering.
Before Structify: You needed data engineers to spend weeks building custom scrapers just to extract basic info from websites. Then hire more engineers to fix broken scrapers. Then wait months to connect your CRM to your product usage data because "the APIs don't talk to each other.‚Äù

With Structify: Describe what you want in plain English, get enterprise-grade data pipelines in minutes. No code. No hiring. No backlogs.

2. Works with any data source.
PDFs, spreadsheets, websites, APIs - we connect and structure everything automatically.
Construction firms turn contracts into searchable databases. RevOps teams get 360-degree pipeline views by connecting CRM, meeting notes, and web research.

3. Enterprise-grade accuracy at machine speed.
The big AI tools hallucinate on complex data. We're built for mission-critical business decisions.
Turn 6 months of data work into 6 minutes of plain English requests.

In 2023, I was staying up all night writing scrapers, PDF parsing rules, connectors from sources, and doing digital data entry manually.

I realized this was fundamentally broken. Every company was hiring an expensive data team -- or wished that they had one -- to do work that AI could automate.

Today, 40+ companies use Structify to:

- Automate 45-min manual tasks into 30-sec workflows
- Turn millions of documents into clean data
- Connect disparate sources across their org
- Build massive datasets from the web
- Save months of engineering time every quarter

Watch our launch video to see exactly how "can you connect these systems?" becomes "done, here's your dashboard."

We just gave a company 100+ hours back every single month with one tool. Here's how we did it:

Doyanen Hotels has been fighting disparate data for years.

With five properties in Osaka and international expansion plans, their team was stuck spending 100+ hours monthly wrestling CSVs from consultants.

Their legacy data provider capped them at monitoring ~10 competitors when they needed dozens. 

Updates came weekly or daily, useless when hotel rates shift by the hour, leading to revenue managers making pricing decisions on old data.

So they built their own competitive intelligence pipeline from scratch with Structify.

Not another vendor dependency. Complete ownership.

Now they scrape unlimited competitors daily. Every room type. Every promotion. Every restriction.

PMS + OTA + POS data flows into one unified system. No CSVs. Just APIs and real-time truth.

Leadership gets live dashboards. Property performance. Competitor benchmarks. Market gaps lighting up like opportunities.

The verified results:

- 100+ hours saved monthly
- ADR and RevPAR improved
- Expansion modeling accelerated

While competitors wait for vendor updates, Doyanen adjusts pricing in real-time.

While others guess at market gaps, Doyanen sees them first and captures them.

While the industry accepts "that's how hospitality data works," Doyanen rebuilt the entire game.

If your team is burning 100+ hours monthly on manual data work, shoot me a message - we can help.
